intro: Agalinis georgiana, commonly known as the Georgia false foxglove, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the Acanthaceae family and is characterized by its erect, hairy stems and opposite leaves. The plant produces showy, tubular flowers that range in color from pink to purple, typically blooming in late summer. It thrives in moist, sandy soils and is often found in open woods and along stream banks. Agalinis georgiana is a perennial herb that plays a role in supporting local pollinators.
